abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Education Project in Liberia
            was achieved. The Bank's supervision was, on the whole,
            properly timed. However, the project could have benefited if
            more time was spent by the architect on project sites. The
            delays in the implementation of the fellowship program might
            have been avoided, or at least minimized, if the Bank had
            insisted that the Government secure the services of an
            experienced agency to assist it in placing candidates in
            overseas institutions. This was eventually done later (1980)
            during project implementation when the Government signed a
            contract with an American university to administer the
            fellowship program. Maintenance of the vehicles procured
            under the project could perhaps also have been improved if
            the Bank had taken measures to assist in introducing at
            least a basic vehicle maintenance training scheme. An
            important lesson for the Bank is that in the future,
            adequate provision should be made for financing local costs
            for vehicle maintenance and spare parts before financing a
            large number of vehicles in countries which have unusually
            bad roads, poor system of vehicle maintenance and limited
            recurrent financing.
